ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Shipping Commission: Restrictive Work Practices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 14 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What restrictive work practices are in force at the Australian Shipping Commission and its subsidiaries, which, in the opinion of management, reduce productivity without any compensatory safety or industrial health benefits.

(2) What restrictive work practices in force at the Australian Shipping Commission and its subsidiaries, while having some safety or industrial health benefits, are done in such a way that comparable benefits could be achieved with less loss of productivity.
(3) What new restrictive work practices, of the type noted above, have come into force in the last year.
(4) What restrictive work practices, of the type noted above, have been eliminated in the past year and what have been the benefits to productivity in each case.
(5) Has the management advised the Minister for Transport of the total annual cost of these restrictive work practices; if so, what is the total annual cost of these restrictive work practices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(5) When this Government came to office, ANL was a run-down, loss making concern which was virtually bankrupt. This was the result of years of Government mismanagement and neglect. Huge losses had accumulated and inefficient work practices, sanctioned by long practice, were perpetuated.

Recognising that this situation could not be reversed overnight, the Government implemented a range of corrective measures. It provided the Line with the capital base appropriate for an enterprise of its size and importance, restructured its top management and installed a new management team, and gave it a new legislative charter which allows it the flexibility to react to commercial pressures.

Reinvigorated in this way, the Australian Shipping Commission had responded positively to its new commercial charter. Recognising that improved productivity was one of the most important factors in determining ANL's survival and future growth, it has moved towards a smaller, better trained work-force and introduced improved work practices into its ships, terminals and offices. It has reduced its total workforce by some 17% over the past three years, while turning around an operating loss of $18.8m to a profit of $38.2m.

Significant improvements in shipboard work practices have been achieved. An average employment reduction of 2 berths per ship across the ANL fleet was implemented in 1983. As new ships are introduced, manning levels in line with the best Australian practice have been achieved. For example, the ``Australian Trader'' and the ``Australian Advance'' have crews of 25 and 27 respectively, a reduction of 19% and 15% respectively in the crew level of the ships they replaced.

Similarly, ANL has been active in the identification and removal of restrictive work practices in its terminals. It has achieved a significant increase in workforce mobility through roster changes and changes to work practices implemented by terminal management at both its major terminals at Port Botany, Sydney and Webb Dock, Melbourne. Although the benefits of these initiatives have not been specifically quantified the new roster and work arrangements have resulted in substantial improvements in efficiency.

It must also be recognised that there is a limit to what any single shipping operator can achieve in isolation. Most improvements in productivity and work practices can only be achieved in the context of industry-wide initiatives.
To this end, I have promoted change in both the shipping and waterfront industries through the Maritime Industry Development Committee (MIDC) and the Government's waterfront strategy.

Shipping incentives recently announced by the Government endorse recommendations of the MIDC's Report ``Moving Ahead'' which will lead to significant changes to seafarer training, shipboard organisation and work practices. The key element of this package is the introduction of multi-skilled ratings into the industry, which will break down job demarcation and significantly improve shipboard productivity. The immediate gain is a reduction in crews from 26 to 21 on new Australian bulk ships with further reductions possible once training systems are in place and a pool of multi-skilled ratings is developed.
The Stevedoring Industry Review Committee (SIRC) is a major element of the Government's waterfront strategy, announced last December.

The SIRC, set up following the final Report of the Shore Based Shipping Costs Task Force, and being chaired by Sir John Moore, will specifically address management and work practices impacting upon the performance of the stevedoring industry.
ANL will be able to take advantage of both these industry initiatives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware of the expense, inconvenience and loss of business now faced by users of OTC's Minerva Telex system who as a result of the Minerva-Telememo joint venture decision, must now have two different telex numbers for domestic and overseas callers, each on separate services and with different sending means, when many such users changed from Teledata to Minerva in order to avoid the complication of shared telex numbers.
(2) Were Minerva users advised well in advance that their domestic telexes would have to be sent and received by Telememo, with vastly different operating procedures.

(3) Was the argument used to support the joint-venture that there would be significant benefits for all users through the interworking of the 2 systems; if so, what have been the benefits which have so far flowed to Minerva users as a result of the decision.

(4) Will the Minister take action to ensure that the services OTC agreed to provide to Minerva users will be restored; or if not, will he take action to ensure that the problem of different access arrangements for national and international telexes is overcome.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Overseas Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that users of the OTC Minerva system now require two telex numbers, one registered with the OTC Minerva system for international telex and the other residing on the Telecom Telememo system for national telex. While there are some minor sending differences in the two systems these have been readily accommodated by Minerva users. This has been facilitated by an extensive training and educational program conducted by OTC and Telecom since April 1986.

In addition, Telecom waived all Telememo-Telex registration charges for Minerva users to enable over 600 Minerva users to register with Telememo for national telex access at no additional cost. Tariffs to send international and national telex messages remained unchanged, under the revised arrangements.

A joint venture has recently been established by Telecom and OTC to integrate their two existing electronic mail services and, later in 1987, the new joint service will provide access to the national and inter- national telex networks with a single address procedure for the sending and receiving of all telex messages for each individual user.

Whilst some inconvenience has been experienced up to now by OTC Minerva customers, neither Telecom nor OTC is aware of any major expense incurred by those users and there is certainly no knowledge of loss of business.

(2) All Minerva customers were advised two months before the change was made and they have since had almost nine months to adapt to the new procedures for sending telex messages to all destinations via the electronic mail systems. Training in the new procedures has been, and will continue to be, provided where requested.

(3) and (4) Benefits will flow to all users following the launch of the new joint service in 1987 as the integrated service will allow existing telememo and Minerva users access to users on both systems and to correspondents on all the major public electronic mail and telex systems worldwide. Technical development is currently under way to implement these arrangements and I am confident that Australian users will see major improvements in services and facilities offered in 1987.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 10 December 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister obtain from the Department or Statutory Authority concerned details of funds provided over the last 4 Budgets by way of grant, contract, recurrent funding, consultancy fees, property rental, or any other means, for a project or purpose involving any one of the following organisations: Australian Community Health Association, Australian Consumers' Association, Australian Conservation Foundation, Australian Council of Social Service, Victorian Council of Social Service, NSW Council of Social Service, ACT Council of Social Service, Queensland Council of Social Service, S.A. Council of Social Service, W.A. Council of Social Service, Tasmanian Council of Social Service, Australian Council of Rehabilitation of the Disabled, Australian Council on the Ageing, Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, Australian Pensioners' Federation, Combined Pensioners' Association of NSW, Combined Pensioners' Association of Victoria, Collective of Self Help Groups (Victoria), Disabled Persons International, Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, Health Issues Centre (Victoria), National Aboriginal and Islanders' Health Organisation, National Women's Health Association, Brisbane Women's Community Health Centre, Youth Affairs Council of Australia, Student Initiatives in Community Health, Australian National Association for Mental Health, Victorian Mental Illness Awareness Council, Health Consumers' Forum, Rupert Public Interest Movement, Doctors' Reform Society, National Association of Psychiatric Rehabilitation and Support Services, Women Against Poverty and Isolation, Medical Consumers' Association; if so, could details be given of: the amount of money involved, the purpose of the funds, the name and address of the sponsor and/or administrator of the funds, the name and address of other organisations involved in the use of the funds and the program or section of the Budget from which the funds were allocated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Finance does not require, in its dealings with departments and statutory authorities, the provision of the detailed information sought on the financial transactions identified in the question. It would be a costly and time-consuming task to gather such information.

As has been the practice of previous Governments, the Government is not prepared to authorise the use of considerable resources of time and money that would be involved in assembling the information requested.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 10 December 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Table 18 in the Annual Report of the Commissioner for Superannuation covering the year ended 30 June 1985 shows that retired Commonwealth employees receive superannuation pensions ranging from less than $1,000 a year and that a very large proportion of superannuitants are eligible for supplementary social security age pensions. In that context, to avoid disadvantage to those former Commonwealth employees from the recent reduction of 2 per cent in the annual superannuation adjustment as from 23 October 1986, will the Minister confirm that:
(a) there will be an immediate adjustment of the social security age pension supplement to offset the 2 per cent loss; and
(b) those superannuitants will also be entitled to the next half-yearly social security increases available to other age pensioners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Any adjustment to the age pension due to a variation in the amount of superannuation received is made automatically in the majority of cases. There are approximately 750 cases in the ACT where the age pension is adjusted manually on advice from the pensioner.
(b) The part age pension received by persons also in receipt of Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme pension will continue to be indexed on a twice-yearly basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 10 December 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was an expected savings in outlays of $12.6m for 1986-87 predicted during the Second Reading speech for the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill 1986.
(2) As the relevant Act became effective from 10 October 1986, will the Minister for Finance advise-
(a) the offsetting costs due to:
(i) the loss of income tax and Medicare levy which would have otherwise applied to the income lost from 10 October 1986 to 30 June 1987 for some 106 000 payees;
(ii) consequential increases in Social Security pensions and supplements; and
(iii) extra work loads to meet the target date for changeover in the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office, the Department of Social Security and other paying agencies; and
(b) the net result of these adjustments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes
(i) Loss of income tax and Medicare levy are estimated to be $2.8 million in the last 1986-87 financial year.
(ii) It is estimated that total Social Security pension outlays will increase by about $1 million in 1986-87. The effect on unemployment, sickness and special benefit outlays will be negligible.

(iii) The Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office estimates that the cost of overtime to meet the implementation of the 2% discounting was about $12,000. The impact on the Department of Social Security was not significant enough to warrant a demand for additional resources.
(b) The net saving during 1986-87 is expected to be about $8.8 million.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are war widows now required to notify the Veterans' Affairs Department every quarter regarding reimbursement of travel costs incurred when visiting their doctor.
(2) Are war widows now applying annually told that they will receive only the last quarter's expenses thus losing three quarters of their entitlement.
(3) Why did the Department of Veterans' Affairs fail to notify war widows of entitlement for reimbursement of travel expenses.
(4) What are the additional costs incurred by the Department of Veterans' Affairs as a result of processing these travel entitlements quarterly rather then annually.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. With the introduction of the Veterans' Entitlements Act on 22 May 1986 all Repatriation beneficiaries have been required to lodge claims for reimbursement of travel expenses within 3 months of the completion of that travel.

(2) The application of this limitation would hinge entirely on the circumstances of each individual case and acceptance of the claim may vary depending on whether or not there exists an ongoing need for specific treatment involving travel.
(3) This policy will be administered sympathetically and compassionately taking into account the general thrust of the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

(4) On 9 February 1983, I announced the formation of the Advisory Committee on Repatriation Legislation Review to present the views of Veterans and their dependants. The Committee included representatives of the major ex-service organisations including the War Widows Guild of Australia. It was the recommendation of this Committee that travel expenses be accepted only if claims were lodged within 3 months of the expense being incurred.

Prior to the introduction of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Department of Veterans' Affairs undertook an extensive publicity campaign to enable the ex-service community to be aware of the provisions of the Bill and to give them an opportunity to comment.

(5) There are some minimal direct costs involved in administering the 3 months' time limitations but these are off-set by the savings in the extensive administrative effort involved in verifying claims submitted for travel undertaken many months, and sometimes years, earlier.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 20 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Veterans' Affairs write to a number of country private hospitals on 27 November 1986 advising them that in future veterans would have to obtain prior permission from the Department before they were eligible for free elective surgery from these same hospitals; if so, what were the names of the country private hospitals so advised in each State or Territory.
(2) What was the estimated cost saving to the Government of these new measures.
(3) When were all veterans advised of this change in arrangements; if they were not so advised, why did the Department deem it not necessary to notify the Veterans of these changes.

(4) Is it a fact that as a result of these new measures, some veterans will have to join private health funds-with the resultant one year delay before they are eligible for health care benefits-thereby adding to the queues of the people who need elective surgery.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Surgical admissions to private hospitals have always required prior approval. However, on 27 November 1986 my Department did write to a number of country private hospitals advising that, in future, prior approval must be obtained for all admissions of entitled beneficiaries. Previously, my Department had agreements with these particular private hospitals which permitted short-term medical admissions without prior reference to my Department.

(2) Admissions to private hospitals will continue to be approved where early treatment is indicated and cannot be provided through the Repatriation or public hospital system. Each case is determined on its merits. Although private hospitals will continue to be used where the urgency of the medical condition warrants this, the termination of agreements applying to medical admissions offers some potential for savings by removing the opportunity for private hospitals being used in circumstances where the higher cost could not be medically justified. The extent of these potential savings has not been estimated.

(3) It was not necessary to advise individual Veterans of the change in administrative procedures since no action on their part was required. Local Medical Officers and specialists have the responsibility for arranging hospital admissions. All were advised of the revised procedures which had been introduced to ensure that they arranged necessary medical admissions in a cost-effective manner.

(4) No. These revised arrangements do not affect procedures for admissions for elective surgery. Urgent admissions to country private hospitals, at departmental expense, will continue to be arranged when clinically necessary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1986 (Hansard, page 761) Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister for Finance. Her question concerned the estimated $6m shortfall in Queensland's compensation for 1986-87 under the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign, due to a predicted doubling of the number of cattle to be destocked from 60,000 to 120,000. She requested that I support half the destocked cattle being placed in feed lots so that they can be fattened and sold for slaughter, thereby recouping some $3m which could contribute to other aspects of the BTEC program. At the time, I answered the first part of the question regarding the estimated $6m shortfall. The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: In November 1985 Queensland made a submission to the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign (BTEC) Committee requesting $7.7 million in compensation expenditure for 60,445 cattle in 1986/87.
This submission was endorsed by the Australian Agricultural Council and the Commonwealth budgeted for its 75 per cent contribution.
In October 1986 Queensland submitted revised 1986/87 estimates of $16.3 million for compensation for 134,092 cattle, an increase of $8.6 million.

The BTEC Committee Meeting of October 1986 did not endorse the revised Queensland estimate but asked Queensland to re-examine its estimates and to look at options that might extend its compensation funds. The Commonwealth has managed to arrange some additional compensation funding for Queensland which has been derived from saving in other States.

Queensland has a program for lot feeding a number of cattle destocked under the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign. The Commonwealth is not participating in the feed lotting scheme. However I support the proposal that the Queensland Government direct any savings back into the eradication campaign.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many inspectors have been appointed under section 21 of the Whale Protection Act.
(2) How many of these inspectors carry identity cards or proof of enforcement powers.
(3) What training, if any, is provided by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service with particular reference to cetaceans.
(4) Which ports are manned, on what basis, so that the Act may be enforced.
(5) How many, if any, permits have been issued by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, with respect to section 11 (1) (b) of that Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No persons have been appointed as inspectors under section 21 of the Whale Protection Act 1980. The Commonwealth has proposed that State and Northern Territory officers who are authorised to perform duties under the Commonwealth's Fisheries Act 1952 and Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968 (the administrative and enforcement costs of which function are reimbursed by the Commonwealth) be also appointed to enforce the provisions of the Whale Protection Act. To date, however, the level of additional reimbursement sought for this function is not considered appropriate in relation to the degree of threat to cetaceans in Australian waters. The Commonwealth is continuing to seek a satisfactory agreement to ensure that enforcement arrangements consistent with the protection requirements of cetaceans are implemented.
(2) Identity cards have been printed and the intention is that each inspector appointed under section 21 of the Act would carry one of these cards.

(3) Australian Government policy on the protection of cetaceans and detailed explanations of the provisions of the Whale Protection Act feature prominently in the contributions made by Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) officers to the regular training seminars conducted by the Royal Australian Navy for Executive Officers and Commanding Officers of patrol boats stationed in Australian waters. Participation of ANPWS officers in these seminars will continue and, following the appointment of inspectors, appropriate training schemes will be established. Meanwhile, draft guidelines for inspectors are being developed in liaison with the Australian Federal and Northern Territory Police Forces (whose officers are ex-officio inspectors) and with relevant Commonwealth and State Departments.

(4) Enforcement of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, under which the importation and exportation of cetaceans, or the products thereof, is controlled, is undertaken by Customs Officers at all major ports in Australia.
(5) No permits have been issued under section 11 (1) (b) of the Whales Protection Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is a Forests Leaflet on wood chipping to be produced by the Australian Heritage Commission in December 1986 under its Information/Education Program 1986-87; if so, could the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment advise-
(a) the purpose of the leaflet;
(b) what will be the contents of the leaflet; and
(c) is there any significance in the timing of the release of the leaflet which coincides with the forests campaign already announced by the conservationists for summer 1986-87.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No leaflet on woodchipping has yet been produced by the Australian Heritage Commission. However the Commission intends to produce such a leaflet in the future as part of its Information/Education Program.

(a) The Australian Heritage Commission has a statutory obligation to heighten public awareness of the issues affecting the national estate, and part of our forests form a major component of Australia's national estate.
At its meeting in July 1986, the Commission recognised that forestry harvesting and woodchipping was likely to be a national estate issue for a number of years.

As a consequence, the Commission saw the need to produce information material which would describe the national estate issues affected by forestry harvesting and woodchipping so that a more informed level of public debate could be promoted.
It was agreed that as part of this process a leaflet should be produced.

(b) The contents of the leaflet have not yet been drafted in detail. I am advised however that it is proposed that it describe the national estate values of places in the Register of the National Estate which are either being, or are likely to be affected by forestry harvesting and woodchipping practices.
(b) The Commission cannot estimate the date when the leaflet will be released. There is therefore no coincidence between the release of leaflet and any summer campaign by conservationists.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 December 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many postage imprint vending machines had been installed by the end of the 1985-86 financial year.
(2) How many more are expected to be operating in the 1986-87 financial year.
(3) What procedures does Australia Post have for the destruction of imprints which are irregular.
(4) Is Australia Post aware of sales by philatelic dealers of imprints on plain stock, on the back of regular stock, upside down on the front of regular stock, or with a zero price reading.
(5) What steps are being taken to lessen the number of such irregular imprints.
(6) In what circumstances will the machines print 00.00.
(7) Are any additional efforts being made to prevent the abuse of such mishaps.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Australian Postal Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Prescribed procedures require that all `no value' or test labels are to be destroyed in the presence of the postmaster.

Generally, Australia Post does not have access to imprints which are irregular as they are retained by the customer. However, in circumstances where irregular imprints are presented to Australia Post by customers for repurchase or exchange, the irregular imprints are sent for destruction. The response to the Honourable Senator's question upon notice number 1584 sets out the prescribed destruction procedures.
(4) Yes.

(5) Australia Post has commenced an internal investigation to determine the possible source or sources of the irregular imprints and to establish revised procedures that will reduce or eliminate such imprints.

(6) The machines will print a 00.00 label as part of the normal daily tests made to ensure that the printers and the control electronics are working satisfactorily. A malfunction may also produce that result.
(7) See (5) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware if any Australians attended the World Peace Council's (WPC) 14th Major Peace Congress in Copenhagen, October 15-19 in 1986.
(2) If Australians were present at the Conference, who were they and which organisations did they represent.
(3) Did the Australian Government sponsor any Australians to attend the Congress; if so, what are the names of the attendees and the organisations they represented.
(4) What are the costs incurred for each attendee by the Australian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am not aware of any Australian attendance at this meeting.
(4) Nil (not applicable).
